issues.title: Ombudsteam confidentiality
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
The Ombudsteam has strict confidentiality rules. I suggest that in https://github.com/larseggert/moderation/blob/main/draft-ecahc-moderation.md#relation-to-ombudsteam we should say something like:

The Ombudsteam has strict rules of confidentiality. If a moderation case overlaps with an Ombudsteam case, confidential information SHOULD NOT be shared between the teams unless there is no practical alternative. In any such case, the members of the moderation team MUST treat this information according to the Ombudsteam rules {{BCP25}}.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: LGTM. Do you want to do a PR or should I?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Please go ahead, I haven't cloned the repo.

~~Ok with me. Could you prep a PR?~~

issues.title: What about interactions with NomCom
issues.author: JayDaley
issues.body: The doc is silent on any potential interactions with NomCom and it may be sensible to address those.  For example, if someone stood for a role and the moderation team had received abusive private messages from that person in relation to a moderation action, then they should be allowed to tell NomCom about that.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
I'm not sure about this. To begin with there's some confidentiality text in the Ombudusteam relation section that would contradict this advice.

Secondly, isn't there a more general issue that anyone in the IETF, when providing nomcom feedback, may use the context they have with the candidate (public and private) to provide feedback? Of course naturally omitting any sensitive details, but ... this isn't specific to the moderators. If I'm a WG chair and I don't like the interactions with person X, that may reflect on my nomcom feedback for X.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, anyone who's had negative (or positive) private dealings with a candidate can choose to share that with NomCom. I don't see that dealings with the moderation team are more confidential than any other private dealing. (That is *not* true for the Ombudsteam, however.)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Discussion so far seems to lean towards closing this issue with no action - or does someone want to propose a PR with a change?

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: I think we should close without a change.

issues.title: Be clearer about what's unified
issues.author: jariarkko
issues.body:
The introduction starts with "This document proposes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels." And the motivation part starts with ombudsteam/harrassment and continues to discuss moderation, split between different moderators on various WGs and lists, and PR-actions.

I don't feel the document does a good job of explaining what's actually being unified in a single team. Intro seems to imply it is the different types of channels. When we started the email thread I thought this was about all non-WG lists and different tooling (chat etc). Scope section seems to say that it is all lists and meetings and chat. But the ombudsteam part is still clearly not in it.

I think there's some room for discussion here perhaps on what we are actually proposing. Are WGs in it or not? And WG meetings? I'm fine whatever the answer is but we should be clear about it. (I do think though that tracking all WG lists may be a large task for a single moderation team.)

I think the introduction should clearly lay out what the unification is, e.g., 

OLD:
This document proposes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels.
NEW:
This document proposes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels. This includes all WG and other mailing lists, chat and other virtual presence tools, and all virtual and in-person meeting activities. The moderator team will work with the ombudsteam that continues to be in charge of addressing any harassment that may occur in the IETF.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
> I do think though that tracking all WG lists may be a large task for a single moderation team.

It's impossible, not "large". That's why I think the normal mode should be that WG Chairs initally handle a case and then call in the moderators if the issue continues.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: The original idea was to have this team do *everything*, including WGs. This would of course rely on chairs and participants who flag problematic behavior to the team. (Whether chairs still MAY/SHOULD take action themselves is IMO TBD, I can make arguments both ways.)

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Yes, I understand that but let me quote my whole email on this point:

> "TODO: Decide whether moderation rights remain also with WG chairs, list admins, and others who currently have them, or whether all moderation rights centralize with the moderator team. I somewhat prefer the latter, since it'll be cleaner."
> 
> I think that some WG chairs might like this, and others might hate it as reducing their role. How about saying that a WG Chair MAY invoke the moderator team at any time after a disruptive message exchange starts and SHOULD do so if the matter is not resolved within one week?
>
> Otherwise I fear that we will have created an unscalable solution, rather than providing assistance to WGs in difficulty. (Do we have any data on how many disruptive message exchanges are in progress at any one time?)

Just think how big the team would need to be to watch all WG lists! I really don't see any alternative to having WG chairs or list admins call them in when needed (or any participant if the chairs/admins are inactive).

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Agreed. But the thing we need to decide on is if chairs/admins can/should still do their own moderation, or if their (new) role is to merely alert the moderator team and let them take action.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Maybe that should be an open question in the draft, so that WG Chairs themselves can express an opinion?
Personally, if I was still a WG Chair, I think I'd want the right to attempt moderation, with the "professional" team as backup. But other WG chairs might have a different opinion.

issues.title: Moderation criteria and processes
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: I think in Section 4.1 or elsewhere this document needs to say something about how the moderation team will develop its criteria and processes, and how much community review will be involved before those are finalized. It may be important to explicitly state that those things should be living documents and not RFCs.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Good idea. Could you prep a PR?

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: Sure.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
> The moderator team's criteria and 
> processes SHALL be developed with community input _and made public_

(I'm not quite sure how to patch a PR...)

issues.title: Core set of channels for proactive monitoring
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: Should the document specify a core set of channels that the moderator team will proactively monitor? Say, ietf@ and last-call@, at a minimum?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Good idea. Could you prep a PR?

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: Sure. Do you think those two are the minimal set or are there others that you would want the team to keep an eye on? Any Zulip or Slack channels? Or maybe some catch-all to describe the general channels where you want them to proactively monitor?

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Yes I think that PR is fine and we can adopt it and close this issue.

issues.title: Repos, wikis, etc.
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: The intro says that moderation procedures for Github repos, wikis, etc. are undefined -- and then doesn't define anything to address this. Should a placeholder at least be included to note this for further discussion?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I had hoped that talking about "all participation channels" would make this clear, but maybe it's not clear enough? Suggestions welcome.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body:
This is the part that confuses me:

> This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals (no less than three) that SHALL moderate all the IETF's various current and future participation channels. At present, those include mailing lists, chat channels, and in-person and remote meetings.

The first sentence says "all" but the second sentence does not include Github or wikis. Are they supposed to be included or not?

Also, what does it mean that the moderators have to moderate in-person and remote meetings. Does their remit extend to live interactions at the mic? Does it include interim meetings? I suspect it might be simpler to leave WG chairs (or other conveners of meetings, like the IAB) with moderator privileges for live conduct. However, live conduct could potentially factor into a pattern of behavior that the IETF moderator team deals with that also includes textual interactions.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Again, I agree with Alissa. We can't reasonably take the WG chairs and the like out of their role of managing a meeting. Doesn't mean that moderators cannot be consulted or learn about patterns, etc.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
Maybe:

This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals (no less than three) that SHALL moderate all the IETF's various current and future participation channels. At present, those include mailing lists, chat channels, and discussions in other systems that the IETF or the WGs have chosen to employ, such as GitHub, Wikis, and issue trackers.

The management and moderation of in-person, remote, and interim meetings remains a task of the relevant group's management, such as WG chairs. However, it is expected that moderators are available for consultation and assistance should issues arise, and may confer with the group management over potential patterns of behavior.

issues.title: Confidential information
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: I do not think confidential information should be shared between the ombudsteam and the moderator team under any circumstances.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
My concern is that there might be cases where moderation is being gamed as a form of harassment. So the Ombudsteam might _need_ to warn the moderation team that something stinky is going on. And if they do that, they will need to name individuals. That needs to be treated as strictly confidential information by the moderators.

This isn't transitive: moderation is mainly a public operation anyway.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: I think this is probably a tiny corner case and it's not worth sacrificing the ombudsteam's confidentiality obligation over it. It can be scary enough to approach an ombudsperson with a complaint; having the confidentiality circle extend to an extra set of people whom the complainant does not trust could be a deterrent to people using the ombudsteam.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: FWIW I agree 100% with Alissa on this

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
Maybe:

OLD:
If a moderation case overlaps with an ombudsteam case, confidential information SHOULD NOT be shared between the teams unless there is no practical alternative. In any such case, the members of the moderation team MUST treat this information according to the ombudsteam rules {{!RFC7776}}.
NEW:
If a moderation case overlaps with an ombudsteam case, confidential information MUST NOT be shared between the teams.

issues.title: Email suggestions from @richsalz
issues.author: larseggert

[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/3m1ny_Zjhxfy8vTqp14cSgQsO84) from @richsalz:
>I am posting to the gendispatch list because that is where the document says discussion should happen.

>

> 
>In section 4.1, Scope, the sentence “If is not expected that the moderator team will be monitoring every IETF channel…” should appear much earlier in the document.

And if so, is it reasonable to expect that the IETF Chair having decided will change their mind? Isn’t disagreements with IETF Chair decisions can be appealed?

issues.title: Email suggestions from @ekr
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/x1JcEWRYy8_NXE07DqdkCWXr1lQ) from @ekr:
```
I think this is a good idea and this draft is a good start. I have
made a few comments below, but I want to make one general suggestion
for enhancement.

In my experience one of the things that makes moderation difficult
is when each moderation decision is itself subject to extensive
debate in the same venue as it is happening. This constitutes a
DoS on the venue as well as discouraging strong moderation. I
think it would be good to establish a separate venue for debating
moderation discussions (e.g., an issue tracker or something)
that is distinct from the lists being moderated. This will allow
for public debate where necessary but not subject everyone else to it.


S 4.1.
   The moderator team SHALL operate according to a consistent and
   uniform set of criteria, processes, and actions.  The moderator team
   SHALL independently define and execute their role.  They SHALL
   maintain a public set of moderation criteria, processes, actions, and
   other material that allows the community to understand and comment on
   the role of the team.  The moderator team SHOULD consider adopting
   moderation criteria, processes, and actions that other technical
   communities have found suitable.  The moderator team's criteria and
   processes SHALL be developed with community input, but they are not
   expected to be documented in the RFC series.

So these do not require approval of IAB or IESG?

   The moderator team MAY initiate moderation actions by itself;
   individual participants SHOULD also alert the team to disruptive
   behavior they observe.  Participants should be able to contact the
   moderator team in ways that are, ideally, integrated into the various
   participation channels the IETF offers.

I think you should clarify that this is confidential.


Maybe I'm missing it, but it's not clear to me what the *powers*
of moderators are. For instance, can they ban someoen entirely
from a list? From an IETF list? It just seems to say "moderation
actions". FWIW my view is they should have quite broad powers.



S 4.2.

   Because the IESG and IAB are in the appeals chain for moderator team
   decisions (see Section 4.3), the IETF Chair SHOULD NOT appoint a
   moderator who is serving on the IESG or IAB.

I think this should probably be a MUST and I would change it to
forbid someone becoming a moderator and then joining the I*.

   Because the IESG and IAB are in the appeals chain for moderator team
   decisions (see Section 4.3), serving members of the IESG and IAB
   MUST NOT serve as moderators.

I don't see a clause that allows replacing moderators. That seems
like it needs to exist.

S 4.4.
   Due to the global nature of the IETF, the membership of this team
   SHOULD reflect a diversity of time zones and other participant
   characteristics that lets it operate effectively around the clock and
   throughout the year.  Team diversity is also important to ensure any
   participant observing problematic behavior can identify a moderator
   they feel comfortable contacting.

This seems to implicitly assume a very high level of responsiveness
(24x7). I'm not sure that's necessary but if you think it is, then
you should say so.
```

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
And @mnot responded with
```
Piggybacking additional feedback on EKR's because I agree with much^H^H^H^Hall of it.

> On 7 Jul 2023, at 6:04 am, Eric Rescorla <ekr@rtfm.com> wrote:
[...]
> In my experience one of the things that makes moderation difficult
> is when each moderation decision is itself subject to extensive
> debate in the same venue as it is happening. This constitutes a
> DoS on the venue as well as discouraging strong moderation. I
> think it would be good to establish a separate venue for debating
> moderation discussions (e.g., an issue tracker or something)
> that is distinct from the lists being moderated. This will allow
> for public debate where necessary but not subject everyone else to it.

This is a very good suggestion, provided that we very firmly move that discussion there. I'm not sure folks have the discipline.

> S 4.1.
>    The moderator team SHALL operate according to a consistent and
>    uniform set of criteria, processes, and actions.  The moderator team
>    SHALL independently define and execute their role.  They SHALL
>    maintain a public set of moderation criteria, processes, actions, and
>    other material that allows the community to understand and comment on
>    the role of the team.  The moderator team SHOULD consider adopting
>    moderation criteria, processes, and actions that other technical
>    communities have found suitable.  The moderator team's criteria and
>    processes SHALL be developed with community input, but they are not
>    expected to be documented in the RFC series.
> 
> So these do not require approval of IAB or IESG?

This is perhaps the most important point. In the past, there have been very strong disagreements about moderation, and questioning of legitimacy of particular actions within the IETF process. Allowing the moderators to 'define [...] their role' and 'adopt moderation criteria' outside of the IETF consensus process opens up a number of questions about how that works, whether the output is legitimate in the eyes of the community, etc. 

> Maybe I'm missing it, but it's not clear to me what the *powers*
> of moderators are. For instance, can they ban someoen entirely
> from a list? From an IETF list? It just seems to say "moderation
> actions". FWIW my view is they should have quite broad powers.

Yes. It'd also be helpful if this draft listed the RFCs the authors believe will be updated or obsoleted if it is published.

> S 4.4.
>    Due to the global nature of the IETF, the membership of this team
>    SHOULD reflect a diversity of time zones and other participant
>    characteristics that lets it operate effectively around the clock and
>    throughout the year.  Team diversity is also important to ensure any
>    participant observing problematic behavior can identify a moderator
>    they feel comfortable contacting.
> 
> This seems to implicitly assume a very high level of responsiveness
> (24x7). I'm not sure that's necessary but if you think it is, then
> you should say so.

If WG chairs lose the ability to moderate (which I know is an open question), handling an issue through a moderator team is going to inevitably add latency. So I think it is necessary -- IME it's much more effective if bad behaviour is caught and stopped early.

To that question of whether WG chairs should still be able to moderate -- I'm not sure, but I observe very different behaviour in different WGs. What passes in some WGs as normal debate would be flagged by chairs as disruptive. Will moderators appreciate these differences, or set a new level for some WGs? And what will that level be?

Whether or not WG chairs still have the ability to moderate, it'd be good to understand what the expected interactions between chairs and moderators would be. E.g., will moderators check in with chairs on a proposed resolution, to get context and assure that it will work in that community? If chairs retain the ability to moderate, do they need to inform moderators when they act? Etc.

Finally, an editorial nit: I found Section very difficult to read, in part due to the liberal sprinkling of references throughout the text. It might help to move references to the end of the applicable sentence, where possible.


```

issues.title: Email suggestions from John Levine
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/2H9subWDn6IRvkXAPhCT54PF6d8) from John Levine:
```
While I think the idea of this draft is fine, I do not understand the 2119 language.

In other RFCs, 2119 language tells you how to interoperate.  You MUST do this or
your system won't interoperate with others.  But here, for example:

 This IETF moderator team ... SHALL moderate all the IETF's various
 current and future participation channels. 

I hope they do, but if they don't, what happens? It starts an appeal?
The moderators are fired? The IETF sinks further into chaos? 

I'd replace the 2119 stuff with normal English or else replace the
boilerplate paragraph 2 with an explanation of what SHALL, MUST NOT,
etc. mean in this context.
```

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I think the 2119 language adds clarity, but I could be convinced to lowercase.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
It's a general problem with process documents, because 2119 was really aimed at technical specs. Maybe this document can set a precedent - define its own terminology text instead of citing RFC2119/8174:

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this
document are to be interpreted  in their normal English sense; they are shown
in uppercase for emphasis and clarity.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @becarpenter would you prepare a PR so we can see how that would look like?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: PR just sent

issues.title: Email suggestions from @chris-box
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: Email suggestions from @chris-box (sent privately, so not included here)

issues.title: Definition of "moderation" in the IETF context
issues.author: paulehoffman
issues.body: The draft does not define what the moderator team is and is not allowed to do. This is important because online moderation normally involves removing posting, whereas in the IETF context it only means limiting new posting by an individual. If this draft intends to allow removing of messages from mailing list archives (and I sincerely hope it doesn't!), it needs to say so clearly. If it doesn't intend to allow removing of messages from mailing list archives, it needs to say that so that readers outside the IETF context understand that this is different than all the social media platforms they are familiar with.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I think we do very occasionally remove messages that are clearly criminal or utterly unacceptable. Certainly we need that option, for legal reasons if no other, but I agree that we need a definition of "normal" moderation.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: There is a TODO in the current revision on whether the document should define some fenceposts for moderation. (Removing messages from the archives is typically done because of legal risks, i.e., is an LLC decision.)

comments.author: paulehoffman
comments.body: Good enough that you have a TODO. I'll close the issue.

issues.title: Scaling (1)
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
The draft has two TODOs that amount to the same thing: "Decide whether moderation rights remain also with WG chairs, list admins,..."

This is a scaling issue: there is no way that a small team can pro-actively moderate hundreds of lists. So it seems evident to me that existing list admins must be the first line (whether for WG or non-WG lists). The only exceptions might be a handful of IETF-wide lists, notably ietf@ and last-call@ (as the draft already says).

Of course that interacts with the BCP83 discussion.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: That WFM, but then we should make it clear(er) that chairs (and community members?) MAY/SHOULD inform the moderators about potentially problematic behavior.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, indeed, I guess it's SHOULD for chairs and non-WG list admins, and MAY for the community.

issues.title: Scaling (2)
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
> This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals (no less than three)

Three is certainly too small. Perhaps change it to "(no less than five)", or omit the parenthesis completely to avoid micromanagement.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
Yes, that trips people up constantly. Maybe
```
This IETF moderator team consists of no less than three individuals,
to establish some minimum basis for consensus-based team decisions
and geographic spread, but realistically needs to have several times that
number of members to spread the moderation load and provide redundancy
in the cases of absences, etc.
```

comments.author: JayDaley
comments.body: If you have several time 3, i.e. 21, then do they all need to reach consensus on any decision?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I didn't mean we need always a multiple of three, just maybe a bunch more than just three. Point about consensus remains.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I don't we should set a hard minimum or a hard maximum. Common sense should apply.

issues.title: Define "moderate"
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
We need to precisely define what we mean by "moderate" and "moderation".

See this message for context:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/i74Ey8_aFRqekH4n2d6Ha412hSk/

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
Yes, we should be explicit about this being a spectrum all the way from gentle reminders on- and off-list, all the way to suspension of posting rights and other ways of participating/communicating.

We need to make sure the I-D doesn't go to far into policy-setting territory though; that IMO the team needs to do for itself.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Maybe state something like: The term "moderation" can refer both to _preemptive_ moderation, where a moderator reviews messages before release to the mailing list, and _reactive_ moderation, where the moderator intervenes after a message has been sent. The IETF mainly practices reactive moderation, with a spectrum all the way from gentle reminders on- and off-list, all the way to suspension of posting rights and other ways of participating/communicating.

PR?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: WFM. Yes, PR please?

issues.title: Who chooses the moderators?
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
There have been several email comments objecting to "The IETF Chair appoints members of the moderator team." The concern is that this might end up with the Chair being conflicted when a moderation "case" involves the Chair (or maybe the IESG).
Should the moderator team be appointed by a community process? If so, how, since NomCom is already overloaded?

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: I think this is a red herring and the people who hold this objection do so because they want to be able to claim that the IETF Chair is censoring them and the moderator team is compromised when the IETF Chair disagrees with things they say and do.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: That's exactly what they claim. I'm not supporting them necessarily, but should we note this in the draft as an open issue?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
I see no good solution here. And the chair already appoints the current moderator team and the ombudsteam. 

Any machinery we invent (multiple appointment roles/bodies, NomCom, etc.) feels like overkill.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: Agree with @larseggert.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: We could go to a model that I had been using for those two teams, I.e., have them search and nominate new candidates for the team with the chair merely approving.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
That's good, and should probably be documented for the Ombudsteam too.
Do we also need to discuss how a moderator is removed?
Also we need a conflict of interests section, like section 7 of RFC 7776. What happens if the Chair is involved directly in a moderation "incident"?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
>  Do we also need to discuss how a moderator is removed? 

Either they step down, or the others ask the chair to remove them for <reason>.

>Also we need a conflict of interests section, like section 7 of RFC 7776. What happens if the Chair is involved directly in a moderation "incident"?

The chair should not.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: It shouldn't ever happen. But sometimes bad things do happen...

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Could we see some discussion on #55, specifically whether we need to describe in this I-D how moderators are removed from the team if we go to a "team self-selects, chair confirms" model?

issues.title: Emergency actions for egregious postings
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
I think we should explicitly authorise a few people to take emergency action when a completely unacceptable posting is made (illegal, vulgar, or manifestly harassing). For example, the IETF Chair, the Exec Dir, and maybe a couple of backups, could instruct staff to delete a given message and/or block a given poster, subject to follow-up within 48 hours by the moderation team or to referral to the Ombudsteam.

(I think the staff already have discretion to delete manifest spam, but I'm not sure where that is written down.)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Agree. But we also need to handle the case where a participation channel gets DoS'ed.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, staff must be able to respond immediately to DoS without any delay.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Based on experience, staff will very often want sign-off from leadership or the community.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, that makes sense, but we need language that allows for true emergencies,

issues.title: Point to and summarize relevant material from `draft-perkins-irtf-code-of-conduct`
issues.author: larseggert

issues.title: Create a new subsection in Introduction to cover goals
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
Be explicit about what the goals of the work are.  Are they?

- Inclusive environment through enforcement of IETF code of conduct
- More responsive approach
- Don't create community food fight?
- Minimal intervention to enforce IETF code of conduct
- Hold precious community resources
- Maintain dignity of all individuals
- Transparency
- Fairness

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I think we'd need consensus on these first before we can talk about adding a subsection for them. (I would argue that some are more important than others, and some might not make the cut for me personally.)

comments.author: elear
comments.body: Fixed by #103.

issues.title: What should be defined now and what by the moderation team?
issues.author: elear
issues.body: Currently the draft leaves a lot of process for the moderation team to define.  On the one hand, we do not want to tie the hands of moderators, and on the other hand, our RFCs are normally the way we define process.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I think I heard some support for putting in fenceposts in the draft, but letting the moderators then define processes and procedures within those fenceposts. To me, the fenceposts have overlap with the goals you started listing in #67.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: So I think this has to go to the list as well, but I want us to be clear on the differences.  I think that's best done on a call.

issues.title: What level of transparency
issues.author: elear
issues.body: The draft currently states that the moderation team should maintain a public mailing list to discuss not only general moderation topics and policy, but individual moderation decisions.  That may simply move the food fight from one list to another.  But some level of transparency to the community is necessary.  Where is the line?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
We have evidence that discussing moderation decisions on an open list is conducive to toxic loops and harmful to individual dignity. As long as we have appeal paths, I think we should tip the balance towards confidentiality.

On the other hand, I think that the final decision that X has been banned from posting needs to be public.

issues.title: Reinstatement requests
issues.author: elear
issues.body: The draft is silent on review of previous decisions.  Currently BCP 83 permits such review after a period of time.  It is possible that this should be left to the moderation team to define as a process, but it may also be possible to simply specify a time frame in this draft.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: #72 duplicates this issue and has gotten comments; closing this in favor of that.

comments.author: elear
comments.body:
This is distinct from #72 as follows:

- This issue: someone wants to plea for reinstatement after having been banned for a Long Time under by moderators under **this** scheme.
- #72: what to do about those who were banned under the previous BCP83 scheme.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: It's not clear at all whether the to-be-defined fenceposts will let someone make that plea.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: Fair enough, but it's a discussion point

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Since the IETF is not a dictatorship, I think we have to have some general principle about this (a fence post if you like). Something like: there MUST be a discretionary mechanism for repealing a suspension after a specified time has passed.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: @becarpenter ok, I think I have an idea on how to split this baby.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: @becarpenter please have a look at #107

issues.title: relationship between moderators and WG chairs / others
issues.author: elear
issues.body: Because we are tasked with covering **all** communication channels, the relationship between moderators and the WG chairs and others must be defined in some way.

issues.title: Review of previous bcp83 actions
issues.author: elear
issues.body: Brian Carpenter has raised the point about what to do about previous moderation decisions.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
There might be 3 options:
- confirm all existing suspensions of posting rights
- remove all existing suspensions of posting rights
- review all existing suspensions of posting rights within X months
My underlying concern is that we must not leave any ambiguity; the secretariat needs precise instructions.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: The fourth option would be to simply say that the moderation team MAY develop processes to review suspensions that existed prior to this document's approval.  We should not require it, however.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: My underlying concern is that there's an issue of natural justice here - when we introduce a new regime, we cannot leave the people sanctioned under the previous regime in limbo. We MUST state what happens to existing suspensions.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
A review of decisions under BCP83 is up to the IESG, and I don't think this draft needs to say anything about them.

Whether there will be a (periodic) review for actions taken after this draft takes effect as a BCP depends on what the fenceposts or the team-defined processes say, IMO.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: If this document obsoletes RFC 3683, which I certainly hope it does, we have no choice but to specify what happens to existing suspensions; the same goes for any other documents that we obsolete. Perhaps the conclusion would be that the IESG decides, but it's really not acceptable to leave this undefined.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: It's not undefined; they are for the IESG to reconsider. I'd like to avoid grandparenting these old PR actions into the new process.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: @larseggert I think we can just reiterate your point in the draft, but this should be taken back to the list.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I think we disagree considerably on this, but yes it's one for the list and I just sent a message.

issues.title: You can always write somewhere else
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
My draft says:

```Anyone can start a blog, or CC an email to a non-IETF list. There are many venues not subject to IETF moderation.```

I'm not attached to the exact phrasing here, but I do think the general idea should go in.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Agreed, and

```
Such venues may have standards of behavior that differ greatly from those of the IETF.
```

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
The CC list point is important, and part of email, so I think we should keep that part. I wrote this one to make the point:

https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2024Dec/0005.html

If there were some despotic moderator, the message would still show up in private mail and that web archive, exposing their overzealous moderation. I'm sure there are many other ways to do that. It shows that concerns about overreach are a bit overstated, imho.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I may be dense, but why do we need to say anything about non-IETF communication/publication channels in this draft?

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Ah. This text intends to point out that you are not being "silenced" if your contribution to an IETF list is held up by moderation. Basically, an IETF list, especially one with wide distribution, is not your blog. My draft has an extra sentence on this point, but I'm not attached to the wording:

> Anyone can start a blog, or CC an email to a non-IETF list.  There are many venues not subject to IETF moderation.
> 
> It may be that the IETF audience's attention is being abused through IETF infrastructure, so that's why this action exists.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Well, I guess I did this (again) on mod-discuss:

https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2025Apr/0001.html

More people will probably read Tim's (it must be noted: extremely mild-mannered) message now than if it just went through.

It is about this draft:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-sayre-modpod-summary/

which is not the one in this repo.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I propose that we close this one.  Not that it's not a valid statement, but as the document has evolved it's become clear that such statements should be made in the ensuing documents developed by the moderation team.

issues.title: Disruptive behavior: arguing counter to the charter of a WG
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
I think this one needs to be covered in some form. For example, if a WG is chartered to encrypt DNS, it is disruptive to jump in and argue against encrypting DNS.

It is OK to question anything in the IETF at least a few times, but repeated derailments of this sort are all too common. These can be really bad, because the responses often start to get rude. Then, the original poster might say "I can't believe this uncivil behavior!", but of course they are just trying to gum up the works. Then, some third party will read that thread and think "what a fiasco."

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: Maybe the more general point here is that it's possible to be disruptive while remaining polite.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Dear Rob,
You are quite correct. It is very possible to prolong a discussion indefinitely in a very courteous manner, by repeatedly asking for more clarifications, for example. Perhaps you would care to expand your point?
Yours sincerely,
   Brian

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I'd really like to avoid listing all the ways in which someone can be obnoxious/disruptive/anti-social/etc. in this draft.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Well, BCP 83 covers it this way:

> Although not exhaustive, examples of abusive or otherwise inappropriate postings to IETF mailing lists include:

I think this kind of thing should be in that short list, but I am not sure how to phrase it (yet).

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: That list in BCP83 is actually why I think we should **not** do a similar list here - it has repeatedly been a source of arguments when people say their post wasn't exactly of  a type listed there, and BCP83 should therefore not be invoked. And when it was pointed out that the list was examples, the response was "who are you to make the call on my thing"...

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Avoiding that problem is the aim of most of my PRs and Issues, as described here:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/mod-discuss/CsIGLns50aHAVgVrbGYt5UXJwCI/

> I do want to eliminate the sense of aggrievedness at any quick moderation action, and eliminate the public shame when someone is briefly not at their best.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: This gets to the point I made on the list: _all moderation decisions are subjective judgment calls_. I think we need to acknowledge that - I'm not completely against listing examples, but Lars is correct that any such list will be debated (for reasons related to why lists of discriminatory words are debated - honest people disagree).

comments.author: elear
comments.body: What is the status of this issue?

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: When I filed this issue, I was wrongly assuming there would be a bulleted list like the one in RFC 3683. We should still do it, but maybe in an appendix supplied as a starting point for the moderation team. I think they'll be implicitly starting from there anyway, and we can throw Sealioning in, too.

comments.author: elear
comments.body:
@sayrer I have no problem with such an appendix as long as it is clear that-

- the examples are non-normative and by no means exhaustive, and
- every case needs to be evaluated in an appropriate context.

Do you want to create a PR?

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
I'll do a PR soon. It will be "Appendix C. Starting Points".

That should write itself, and the title prevents rules lawyering. The difficult part is writing it without the passive voice ("it is expected that..." etc).

issues.title: Moderation must be transparent at least to the person being moderated
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
This is copy/paste from the list, just so it doesn't get lost in the mix.

The person being moderated must be informed. It's unfortunate that we have
to say this, but we've had problems with that in the past. Think of actions
such as a chair removing someone from a list without informing them, etc.
I've never seen anything like that, but I have heard stories of such
chicanery, and I think that's why some people that have been in the IETF
for a long time lean toward too much immediate transparency.

After all, if these actions are subject to appeal, the person has to know
about them.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I agree with this. Want to propose a PR?

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: I'll do so. I think it would be best to clear up the in-flight PRs first, though.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: This needs repairing.  I rebased my way into Hell!

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @elear which PR needs repairing? (Because this is an issue.)

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: I think this one eventually got fixed in #91.

issues.title: Hypocrisy
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
My draft has this section. I don't really like most of the text. I just hammered it out in about two minutes. But I do think one sentence is good: "The IETF will treat people with kindness and grace, but not endless patience."

I'd like to save that one.



> Hypocrisy
> 
> The hazard in writing any document of this sort is that it seems to presume the authors and supporters are perfect. They are not.
> 
> Everyone makes mistakes. The IETF will treat people with kindness and grace, but not endless patience.
> 
> This document describes a two-way street. Moderators must also maintain excellence.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
This one might be good right at the top. If you get pointed at a document with that abstract, that should probably get the point across right away. No need to read all of the detailed rules (which do have to exist).

> The IETF will treat people with kindness and grace, but not endless patience.
>
> This document describes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels. Without removing existing responsibilities for working group management, this team enables a uniform approach to moderation of disruptive participation across all mailing lists and other methods of IETF collaboration.

issues.title: Minimum size of the moderator team?
issues.author: elear
issues.body: The current text talks about five, but my suggestion is that operational experience dictate the team size, not an RFC.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Agree with operational experience. The current doc only (intends to) specify a lower bar on number of members.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I always go back to what Russ Housley taught us: what bad thing will happen if we DON'T put something in a document?  If the answer is "nothing", then don't bother specifying.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I think #76 fixes this (saying `>= 5`).

comments.author: elear
comments.body: IMHO, this is a "small ticket item".  I'm okay closing it, so long as nobody else cares.

issues.title: Should we use 2119 langauge in the draft?
issues.author: elear
issues.body: Rob Wilton thinks "no".

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I don't feel strongly either way. (Yeah, it's not really making sense to do so, but there is ample precedent for process BCPs to do so, and maybe doing so avoids future arguments where someone being moderated objects due to the lack of uppercase wording...)

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Maybe leave this one:

> The IETF moderator team consists of a number of individuals that SHALL moderate all the IETF's various current and future participation channels

and then refer to this RFC to cover the rest of it:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8174

> These words can be used as defined here, but using them is not required.  Specifically, normative text does not require the use of these key words.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
1) I see no reason to avoid RFC 2119 in a process BCP, for the things that we decide really matter.
2) RFC 8174 doesn't change that, it simply makes it clearer.
3) The example quoted is contentious. But that is a point to debate on list when we have a coherent draft posted.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
> The example quoted is contentious. But that is a point to debate on list when we have a coherent draft posted.

Do you mean the quote I pulled from RFC 8174? It might be contentious, but it is right there in a BCP. Sometimes, you have to live with things you don't like. Rough consensus and running code and all that :)

If you mean the sentence I used from the draft, that was intentional. Leave no room for argument. Using the 2119 words sparingly gives them more force.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Sorry, I meant that "that SHALL moderate" is contentious.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: OK. That is exactly the point. Whether we get consensus on that SHALL is up to the WG, but using just one or two of those is a bold move. That is an effective 2119 usage.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: We agree.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I see us adding 2119 terms and not removing them. This seems to indicate that we find them useful. I'm hence inclined to close this as "won't fix".

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I think we need to ping Rob.

comments.author: rgwilton
comments.body:
Pretending that human interactions are like protocol interactions probably will not help make human interactions more friendly and welcoming.

I feel reasonably strongly that 2119 language is overly used in IETF documents such that ends up being less readable rather than more readable, or otherwise jarring, and I think that it would be more helpful for 2119 language to be reserved for network protocols where the extra clarity is important.  

Or perhaps to phrase the question differently, for this document, how does "that SHALL moderate" differ from "that shall moderate"?  If for example, the moderation team, ends up not moderating in one case (for whatever reason, perhaps it is the weekend, or everyone is busy) then does that cause the overall communication to fail?

Having said all that, is this a hill, I'm going to die on?  Nope. ;-)

comments.author: elear
comments.body: @rgwilton I don't think it's a hill ANYONE has to die on.  Just provide a PR, so that we can bicker over phrasing a bit.

comments.author: rgwilton
comments.body: The PR would just be to remove the 2119 reference and uncapitalize when 2119 terms have been used.  I can provide a PR if that helps, but probably needs agreement to make the change first?

comments.author: rgwilton
comments.body: I've now created a PR, in case that is helpful.

issues.title: Requirements on WG Chairs
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body: Since we're aiming for consistency, some of the requirements we make of the moderation team might have to apply to WG Chairs as well. Having never been a chair, I am not sure what's reasonable here. This issue came up in #74. It's probably OK to close some in-flight PRs and then have a look at this one.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Most of that can probably be deferred to whatever guidelines the team provides for chairs.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I like @becarpenter's idea, and in particular we should be careful to not insist on perfect consistency.  The world is too messy for that.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: I also agree with @becarpenter in a sense. It's true that "most of that" can be deferred, but I think there might be some minimum requirements that would be useful to write. Difficult to debate until the document settles down a bit. If there were a concrete action to take, this would be a PR.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I've been starting to think of the chair group as sort of a distributed extension to the moderator team. In that light, the doc could explain how the rules and processes that the moderator team will define (within the fencepost to-be-layed-out in the doc) involve chair (inter-)actions.

issues.title: Moderation during Last Calls
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
**Proposal**
The document should give some brief guidance about Last Call situations.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I think the moderators and chairs should not be able to quietly ban people during Last Calls, if the posts are on-topic. 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Prevent it altogether during Last Call, but I think they should be able to deal with spam and random stuff.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
First, for clarification, you mean during WG last call on the WG list, right? (Because we also have IETF last calls on the last-call list.)

Second, when you say "on-topic" I assume you mean the messages would be related to the document under last call.

Why do you envision the need for two sets of rules, one for during WG last calls and one for other times or for other discussions?

I worry about process complexity.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
"I worry about process complexity."
Yes, but I worry about a very persisent poster whose message is "I've been telling you for two years that this proposal is highly insecure [or contains an unavoidable race condition, or whatever] and you've been ignoring the truth".
Last Call is exactly when this message needs to be heard. So I have some sympathy with Rob's point but I think it's horribly complex and still relies on a judgment call (on-topic or not?).

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
I think it should be non-normative text that briefly describes the purpose a Last Call serves (whether in a WG or the whole IETF) and that the moderators should take this time limit into account.

The idea here is that there are often really annoying posters when a WG starts. That is frustrating because there's no time limit. During a Last Call, if on-topic, it's easy to think: "OK, only another week or two of this person ranting."

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: "Moderation is not a tool for the suppression of unwelcome technical criticisms, especially during Last Calls, whose purpose is indeed to solicit such criticisms and avoid groupthink."

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I'm OK with something like that being added. I just want to caution that we're – in my view – again approaching the "making allowances for brilliant jerks" line, which for me is a red one.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: Without constraining the moderators too much, the action here would be to screen that person's messages. That way, they still get into Last Call traffic without being too jerky.

issues.title: What is a `broad ban`?
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
Current text says:
> All bans longer than fourteen (14) days SHALL be reported to the forum in which the person was banned, and in the case of a broad ban, to the community in a manner decided by the IESG.

**Proposal**
Define what a `broad ban` is. I _think_ it would be `broad ban, i.e., a ban for multiple participation channels`.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Reword `ban` to `moderation action` or something else, but there was concern this would be too noisy.

issues.title: Content takedown
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
**Proposal**
The document considers posting rights pretty thoroughly, but does it cover content takedown? It doesn't make a lot of sense for a mailing list, but it might on GitHub or in chat.

I don't have a prefered solution, but I wondered if it should be covered. This issue came up #92, where it seems the LLC might have to respond to a DMCA takedown request or similar.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I _think_ it's orthogonal. We won't delete disruptive content from mailing list archives, because they are part of the history of how we reached (or failed to reach) rough consensus. If the LLC has to delete something for legal reasons, that is completely distinct from moderation IMHO.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Well, it is a feature of GitHub.

https://docs.github.com/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-conversations/managing-disruptive-comments

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
```
Hidden comments are minimized but people with read access to the repository can expand them.
```
That might be useful, yes, but the full historical record is still there if needed. I think we should forbid redaction and deletion except for legal reasons. (RFC8874 doesn't seem to discuss this but probably should.)

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: Hmm, it would be nice if the comments are also in Git (maybe they are?), so the moderators could delete them but preserve the history.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I agree that we want to preserve the record, but let me give an instance where we might need to delete content: someone creates a really clever bot that pollutes the Internet-drafts directory.  That sort of attack should be dealt with.  Similarly, if someone is using our mailing list archive for, say, botnet C&C, some action might be necessary.  Where does that leave us?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
I think that's housekeeping, not moderation, and should be done by staff.
(via tiny screen & keyboard)
Regards,
        Brian Carpenter

On Thu, 23 Jan 2025, 09:23 RS, ***@***.***> wrote:

> Hmm, it would be nice if the comments are also in Git (maybe they are?),
> so the moderators could delete them but preserve the history.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

issues.title: Timely action is one reason for the 14-day limit
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
**Proposal**
Watching the meeting, I saw some concern about quick action from the moderators without consulting the chairs. One reason the 14-day limit doesn't require public transparency is so that moderators and/or chairs can act quickly, but walk back a decision within a few days if there's been a mistake or there's an adjustment needed. That way someone doesn't called out, and then further called out by a public apology.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
My draft juxtaposed these concepts in 
[0-12](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-sayre-modpod-excellent-02.html#name-0-12-days)

I don't care about the day count. This draft has a more minimal policy (no escalation steps), and something like this will have to match the writing style in this document.

**Additional context**
I would expect the moderators to go with "I'm holding your messages for the chair to review" if there's something borderline. It's probably pretty easy to know what to do with really bad stuff.

comments.author: JayDaley
comments.body: @sayrer My understanding is quite different. Where I thought we settled was that one of the primary reasons for having a moderation team is to increase the chances of swift response when needed.  The issue people had was about the interaction between the Mod team and WG Chairs.  My suggestion, which I think the authors are going to explore, was to define what action the mod team can take when - i.e. to clear state that when rapid action is required, the mod team can do A and B (e.g. put the list into emergency moderation, or put individuals into temporary moderation)  but not C (e.g. block someone from posting altogether), without consulting the WG Chairs, and that when rapid action is *not* required, the mod team cannot act without WG Chair agreement, except D (e.g. when moderating someone across every list).

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
The central problem there is that the mod team cannot possibly monitor all lists 24x7 so the initial alert for a problem should come from a responsible person monitoring the list, and realistically that means a WG chair (or secretary, for WGs that appoint a secretary). Exactly how an incident is handled lies between the WG chairs and the mod team, assuming we don't plan to micromanage this via an RFC. 

One model might be for a WG chair to put somebody into moderation first, and call in the mod team second, but experience might suggest a different approach.

There's a corner case where the WG chairs ignore the problem and some other list member raises the alarm, and another corner case where one of the WG chairs _is_ the problem, but we can't expect to cover all corner cases in an RFC.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
> [@sayrer](https://github.com/sayrer) My understanding is quite different. Where I thought we settled was that one of the primary reasons for having a moderation team is to increase the chances of swift response when needed.

Yes, that is also my understanding. The reason for the day count (14) is so that moderators (or chairs) can act quickly without creating yet more drama.

> The issue people had was about the interaction between the Mod team and WG Chairs.

Yep, #85 is about this one, which I agree is unsettled.

> My suggestion, which I think the authors are going to explore, was to define what action the mod team can take when - i.e. to clear state that when rapid action is required, the mod team can do A and B (e.g. put the list into emergency moderation, or put individuals into temporary moderation) but not C (e.g. block someone from posting altogether), without consulting the WG Chairs, and that when rapid action is _not_ required, the mod team cannot act without WG Chair agreement, except D (e.g. when moderating someone across every list).

I don't think this approach is meaningfully different from what I suggested. It makes some more precise rules, but I'm not sure to what end. Even if the moderators bounce someone's messages for a few days (C), the person can resend them if the chairs decide they are OK, and nothing will be public (but the person being moderated will know).

comments.author: JayDaley
becarpenter
comments.body: @JayDaley, this must vary between WGs; my experience is that WG chairs do jump on poor behaviour in a timely manner. If they don't, I agree that there needs to be a pathway directly to the mod team. But I wrote _should_ (a.k.a. __SHOULD__) because this pathway needs to be the exception, not the rule. Keeping order in the WG is a primary responsibility of every WG chair. "Moderate the WG email list" is a specific chair duty under section 6.1 of RFC 2418.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
@becarpenter @JayDaley I opened the issue because I think any brief moderation action, if not made public, is not too harmful to the moderated participant. It doesn't inhibit contributions. The IETF doesn't move that fast, but email threads can.

So, there's no reason to classify them the way Jay suggests. It does need to be transparent if it's ongoing (hence 14 days).

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I'm not sure what is being proposed.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
OK. In my view, the document needs to explain that the 14-day limit enables quick action. Let's add to your proposed text in #114.

"Moderators may take actions against someone in a working group setting, but they MUST immediately inform management of relevant groups, including WG chairs and area directors, when they do so. The 14-day limit in Section 2.3 exists so that immediate action can be taken, but any disagreements between moderators and list management can be resolved within a few days without public debate."

I am not attached to the words, but that is the reason I put the time limit in my draft. I think some people missed that point, so it is worth explaining that it is intended to mitigate overzealous moderation as well as grant clemency to people briefly not at their best. It is also why I banned myself from the mod-discuss list and this repo for a week. Just to show that a brief timeout is not a big deal in the IETF process, as long as it's not made into a spectacle.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: As long as the text makes it clear that moderating a WG list is _primarily_ the WG chairs' job, and that it's a _failure_ by the chairs if the moderator team has to intervene, then yes, +1 to @sayrer. Anything else simply doesn't scale and invites chairs to duck the hard problems.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: @becarpenter It may not be a failure.  Consider the case when someone has a nutty across multiple lists, and the moderator shuts that person down...

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Hi @elear. The editors could take the first part of @becarpenter's suggestion here

"As long as the text makes it clear that moderating a WG list is _primarily_ the WG chairs' job..."

without accepting the _failure_ part. It is a breadth vs depth situation, right? We'd expect the chairs to deal with trolls that deal with narrow topics, but there might also be people using LLMs to write things like "Thanks for your for your thoughtful comments on [WG subject matter], my solution involves Spam Jamma Pajamas".

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, "failure" is too strong. The case that matters is if the chairs don't act, for whatever reason. But we don't want the existence of the mod team to make chairs believe that they're off the hook.

comments.author: elear
comments.body:
I'll create a new PR for this.  A few points:

* The draft already states in the first sentence of the subsection that WG management is primary.
* The point might get lost in the muddled text that then follows.
* I can add some text around why the 14 day period.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: I think you want to edit that PR to say "Address issue 113"

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
I think the list still doesn't understand this one, looking at the last few days:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/static/mod-discuss/2025-03/

The idea behind keeping things private for a few days is to let someone decide quickly. But the WG seems wrapped around the axle on who can act at all. My point is that the chairs or moderators can do /anything/ for a few days, and it will not impede IETF contributions.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: I don't think they're that wrapped.  I think two people just don't like the idea of moderators at all.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
I think maybe the draft should say both in the Abstract and the first para of the Introduction something like:

_Primary responsibility for moderation lies with working group chairs, but sometimes this needs support from experienced colleagues._

That won't create agreement where it doesn't exist, but I think it will help in clarifying where the disagreement lies.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

My suggestion:

Sections 2, 2.1, 2.2, 2.7, 2.8, and 2.9 are about the team composition and scope.  Let's combine them into a single section (presumably 2).  Section 2.3, 2.5, and 2.6 are about process.  They should be combined into a single section (presumably 2bis/3).  This leaves Section 2.4.  It can reside either in the Section 2 or remain on its own.


**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Optional: A clear and concise description of any alternatives you've considered.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

issues.title: Actions against UBE shouldn't be considered moderation actions that need reporting
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
**Proposal**
Unsoliicited bulk email is disruptive, and therefore falls within the moderation team scope. However, the volume of such material is such that reporting on actions against it will be an onerous workload.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In appendix A, take UBE out of the list, and make a special paragraph for it, saying something like "UBE is considered disruptive, and thus within the moderator scope, but actions taken against it are not considered moderation actions, and don't trigger a requirement for reporting the action to the originator or to the IESG."

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: UBE is also handled via `postconfirm` (i.e, operationally by the LLC), so not much of an issue to begin with.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Should we take it off the examples list altogether, then?
It would be nice to say that "UBE is an operational issue, and can be referred to and be handled by the LLC" - that can also be done in the post-RFC moderation team instructions, it doesn't need to go here.

What I don't want to happen is someone objecting to an UBE action because it was not handled according to modprod procedures, or mod-team time being spent uselessly on UBE-fighting.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
I think it should stay in. There will always be new kinds of spam.

But the document could say that not all moderation actions need detailed explanations, and there are mechanisms in place to deal with obviously off-topic messages.

comments.author: sayrer

issues.title: LLC comments
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
From Jay:

Two parts to this response:

> 1.  Formally on behalf of the LLC given that this intersects with the LLC role in a number of places
> 
> - no concerns with Section 2.1 and the exclusion of staff/contractors from being moderators
> 
> - no concerns with Section 2.2 Training and the implied financial commitment as this is reasonably handled/
> 
> - a concern with Section 3 Roles and Responsibilities and the specification that Moderators are responsible for "attendee lists".  There are at least three of these for different sets of attendees (all, new participants, companions) and they are considered an integral part of the meeting experience and therefore currently moderated by the meetings team.  Also, these lists are opt-in and anyone who chooses not to participate is not disadvantaged when it comes to the standards process, which to my mind differentiates them from plenary fora.  So I would prefer that removed.
> 
> - no concerns with Section 3.2 but a note that if this text was not present then there would be a concern: "Content removal or redaction from IETF archives are not moderation actions, and are therefore also beyond the scope of this memo."
> 
> - no concerns with Section 5.2 "Relation to the IETF LLC" as this is language we proposed 
> 
> 
> 2.  Informally and noting up front that my suggestions below specifically should not be included in assessing the last call, I have the following feedback:
> 
> i) In the Introduction: "It creates a moderator team to draft procedures" —> "It creates a moderator team to define procedures" as 'draft' implies producing something for someone else to approve and "define" is used later in Section 4 where this is elaborated upon though Section 2 uses "develop".
> 
> ii) In 1.2 General Philosophy "The cornerstone of our philosophy is first and foremost the individual, whose responsibility is to further the goals of the organization" —> "The cornerstone of our philosophy is that individuals are responsible for furthering the goals of the organization" because a) both "cornerstone" and "first and foremost" is excessive; and b)  it’s hard to read as is.
> 
> iii) Section 3 "For a Working Group, the chairs should perform moderation in a way that obviates the need for moderator team involvement." seems a bit too much to ask (is moderator action then a grounds to remove chairs?), perhaps "should aim to perform"
> 
> iv) Section 4 "comity" - not only is that an exceptionally unusual word even for native English speakers and therefore making this unnecessarily hard to understand, it is effectively setting a new policy as regards the intent of moderation.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: All subissues resolved.

issues.title: "comity"
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
How about 

"The expectation is that the minimal action necessary to keep a forum productive will be attempted."

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Or:

"The expectation is that the minimal action necessary to keep a forum productive will be taken."

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Attempt 3:

"The expectation is that the minimal necessary action will be taken to keep a forum welcoming and productive."

A problem that "comity" has is that there is often a subtext of dismissiveness, rudeness, or snobbery. Exactly the reason I wrote "superficially polite" in the appendix.

For example, I could say "Thank you for that comment, Lars." That is not cool (and I do not mean it here, it is just to illustrate).

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
We could keep cutting:

"The minimal necessary action will be taken to keep a forum welcoming and productive."

I don't mind that one. But left to the editors.

comments.body: I think the "The minimal action necessary will be taken" is sufficient because a) that's the whole point of this clause; b) the goals are well defined in other parts of the document so referencing them is unnecessary.

comments.author: sayrer

comments.body:
> The word "productive" does not appear anywhere else in this document, so adding it here basically expands the goals. To me that is both unnecessary and problematic. This is why I suggest not giving a secondary goal that distracts from the main point of this sentence.

I get you, but we're trying to remove "comity", which has its own problems. So, what is that thing where everyone can chip in and make the internet better? :) "welcoming and productive" was my best try.

issues.title: Missing a word' in Section 5.2
issues.author: JayDaley
issues.body:
