issues.title: Stephen Farrell comments
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
> Hiya,
> 
> I've only gotten to the end of section 3, but while (so far) the
> substantive content is ready, the -10 text is IMO far from ready.
> I'll send more input as time allows, but for now, see comments on
> sections 1-3 below. To be clear, I do not think -10 is ready for
> a pubreq:
> 
> - there's too much flowery language and I do think that needs fixing
> as it'll cause trouble later if we don't. There are multiple examples
> below, both nits and non-nits.
> 
> - with the (good) definition of "administrators," I'm not sure
> that "moderators" remains a good term for the appointees about
> whom we're writing, more as I finish reading so no need to respond
> to this yet
> 
> More detail below and more to come, time permitting,
> Cheers,
> S.
> 
> ## Specific non-nits:
> 
> - s1.1: "It is up to the moderators..." that seems in the wrong
> place as we've not defined moderators yet and we probably want to
> say administrators. (This isn't a flowery language point:-)
> 
> - s1.1: "decide which mix of preemptive and reactive moderation to
> employ" on it's face would allow a company-X administrator/moderator
> to pre-emptively moderate all emails from any new posters from
> company-Y. I think it's also an important part of the background that
> we don't want that, so suggest adding a sentence about fairness/open-
> ness etc. with some suitable reference. (I don't mind much which text
> or reference and I'm sure the editors could find something fine.)
> 
> - 1.2: "The cornerstone of our philosophy is first and foremost the
> individual," No, it isn't. And that's not even a good sentence. (Am
> I, as an individual, a cornerstone? Are we all? That's a lot of
> corners, and do philosophies even have corners?:-) I'd say delete the
> entire paragraph as it reads like a typically overblown HR statement.
> (Apologies to whoever suggested it - sometimes one just misses the
> target;-)
> 
> - 1.2: "However, when someone crosses the line into disruptive
> behavior, some action must be taken in order to maintain decorum of
> the community." Hmm. I don't think the IETF requires decorum, nor
> have we consensus on such a proposition. My interpretation of
> "decorum" is that it means a thing much stronger than behaving
> well.
> 
> - 1.2: "broadest possible latitude to all people" - I don't like
> that - we do not want moderators to be allowed to delete someone's
> datatracker account from the DB just for disruption for example;
> suggest deleting "the broadest possible"
> 
> - 1.3: Do we recognise that e.g. WG chairs might not in fact be
> able to moderate github discussions (if the repo is owned by an
> author)? I don't think this is the document to propose that all
> WG draft github repos need to belong to a github org that's under
> the control of IETF administrators. Suggest s/are administrators/
> are to be considered administrators/
> 
> - 2.1: the IESG appoints, which is fine, but are those fixed-term
> appointments or not? I figure we need to say.
> 
> - s3: "They are also encouraged to report inappropriate behavior
> directed..." that seems like scope-creep - this is only about
> disruptive behaviour - there's >1 instance of this and it's IMO
> a major point.
> 
> - s3: I had interpreted administrator as "either WG chair or part
> of the moderation team" but now it seems moderation team members
> are not considered administrators. That's fine, but noteworthy
> as I'd assumed the opposite 'till this read-through.
> 
> - s3: "Moderators may take actions when administrators do not
> respond to reports in a timely fashion." - I'll reiterate my
> dislike of this, but also that I can live with the meat of the
> current proposal. (Assuming the text ends up good, which is not
> yet the case.)
> 
> - s3: "moderators are not expected to always actively monitor all
> communications" is way too weak and the wrong way about, I think
> we want to say that moderators should not act unless they have a
> good basis on which to act either based on really knowing the
> forum, or the egregious nature of a posting
> 
> - s3: "cuts across" seems too ambiguous, we do need to try define
> this better, so people know what's what
> 
> - s3: "In order to scale the function, except for plenary fora as
> described above, moderators are not expected to always actively monitor
> all communications.  Instead, they will process reports from
> participants." I don't think "actively monitor" is the opposite
> from "reports from participants" so I'm not happy this is right
> yet.
> 
> - s3.1: As a WG chair, I've been told a few times (by trusted people)
> that person-A had sent bad email to person-B, where bad is not quite
> defined, and I, as WG chair, don't see the content. How do I know if
> that's in or out of scope since I'm an administrator?
> 
> - s3.1: this says "problematic" when the document ought only deal
> with "disruptive"
> 
> ## Nits:
> 
> - abstract: "grace" - I'll take it when I see it, but I doubt
> that "will treat people... with... grace" will often approximate
> truth - I'd suggest removing that. (And IMO no organisation can
> treat anyone with grace, only people can do that.)
> 
> - abstract: "guardrails" - better to avoid AI fashion phrases
> entirely IMO, and guardrails != guidelines which is implied by
> the current text
> 
> - s1: " This memo describes the moderation of disruptive..."
> isn't quite right, the text sets out the team setup and does
> not describe the actual moderation
> 
> - s1.2: "nor should someone be considered disruptive solely
> because they are outside the rough consensus." I'd suggest
> s/should/ought/ here just to avoid the potential BCP14 way of
> misinterpreting that to imply there are cases where someone
> ought be moderated only because they're not part of the rough
> consensus.
> 
> - 1.2: " Apply consistent, fair, and timely moderation of communication
> across all public IETF participation channels and participation
> fora; without regard to one's position or previous contributions;"
> If I squint from a specific angle, I could interpret "one's" above
> to relate to the moderator and not the poster. Both statements seem
> ok, but I think we wanted the latter.
> 
> - s2: "This memo proposes a uniform approach to moderating the
> IETF's various public fora." No, it doesn't. It suggests setting
> up a team to do that.
> 
> - s2: " A moderator team for the IETF will develop uniform
> guidelines" what are uniform guidelines and what could possibly
> be non-uniform guidelines? (Wear a t-shirt and shorts:-) I think
> we want to say guidelines that don't vary by forum-type (WG or
> not etc.) or medium (mail vs. issue-trackers)
> 
> - s2.1: just checking, no strong opinion: "In selecting members,
> the IESG will take into account geographic coverage, expected and
> unexpected absences, and team diversity." - so we do not explicitly
> require the IESG to take into account changes in community views
> of moderation? (That's ok.)
> 
> - 2.2: I think s/moderators/administrators/ here would be better
> 
> - s3: "Administrators* are primarily responsible..." managing disruptive
> postings is not the primary concern of e.g. WG chairs so this
> seems wrong
>

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
> > 1.2: "The cornerstone of our philosophy is first and foremost the
> >  individual," No, it isn't. And that's not even a good sentence. (Am
> > I, as an individual, a cornerstone? Are we all? That's a lot of
> >  corners, and do philosophies even have corners?:-) I'd say delete the
> > entire paragraph as it reads like a typically overblown HR statement.
> > (Apologies to whoever suggested it - sometimes one just misses the
> > target;-)

Well, I don't like that sentence either. But it is not as bad as you say. "Cornerstone" here is a way of saying "foundation". Nothing to do with corners.


> > s3: "In order to scale the function, except for plenary fora as
> >described above, moderators are not expected to always actively monitor
> > all communications. Instead, they will process reports from
> > participants." I don't think "actively monitor" is the opposite
> > from "reports from participants" so I'm not happy this is right
> > yet.

Instead does not mean opposite. It means something like "rather" here.

> >
> > * s3.1: As a WG chair, I've been told a few times (by trusted people)
> >   that person-A had sent bad email to person-B, where bad is not quite
> >   defined, and I, as WG chair, don't see the content. How do I know if
> >   that's in or out of scope since I'm an administrator?

This issue is covered. I don't know how much clearer it could be.

[Out of Scope: Non-IETF Fora, Private Communications, and Content Removal](https://larseggert.github.io/draft-ietf-modpod-group-processes/draft-ietf-modpod-group-processes.html#name-out-of-scope-non-ietf-fora-)
It is important to note that the moderator team only moderates public IETF fora. Their mandate does not extend to problematic behavior in private...

> > * s3.1: this says "problematic" when the document ought only deal
> >   with "disruptive"

Oh, this word is ok with me. It is a word with a definition of: "posing a problem." There is a sense of the word related to "political correctness", but that's not what is meant here. It's obviously not about efforts like "hemispheric sensitivity" (where you take care to note that it is winter in Australia in August, and that it is 6:30pm in Dublin when it is 10:30am in SF). That stuff is exhausting, but there is a more straightforward definition, and it is sense number 1.

> > 
> > * abstract: "grace" - I'll take it when I see it, but I doubt
> >   that "will treat people... with... grace" will often approximate
> >   truth - I'd suggest removing that. (And IMO no organisation can
> >   treat anyone with grace, only people can do that.)

That sentence has it right. "The IETF community" -- those are people. The sentence also serves a purpose. It is to get someone on board without requiring them to read the document. Also, I would find it embarrassing if we couldn't write "The IETF community will treat people with kindness and grace, but not endless patience." Here, we want so many senses of this word: elegance, goodwill, brevity, reprieve, etc.

issues.title: Nit in Section 2.1
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: Nit: Section 2.1: s/The moderators may decide to consult/The moderators may consult/

issues.title: Colin Comments
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
> Hi,
> 
> I support publication, but have one substantive comment and three minor editorial points.
> 
> The substantive point: the draft is clear that it applies to the IETF and correctly states that the IRTF has its own procedures. Unless I missed it, however, there didn’t seem to be a clear statement of whether the procedures described apply to public fora owned by the other streams. For example, the IAB run several public lists, and there is the RSWG list, which I believe are currently moderated outside the IETF PR process. Do they continue to follow their current process or become part of the process described in this draft?
> 
> Editorial:
> 
>     I would suggest the list of changes from Section 1 and the background from Section 1.1 could be moved to an appendix, and that doing so might improve the readability of the document.
> 
>     §1.2 “whose responsibility is to further the goals of the organization” could be changed to “…goals of the IETF as an organisation” to make it clear what organisation is being discussed.
> 
>     §5.3 draft-perkins-irtf-code-of-conduct is now RFC 9775
> 
> Cheers,
> Colin
>

issues.title: Reinstatement only after bans
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: Concern: Section 4 opens with various moderation actions, but Section 4.1 only addresses bans.  No reinstatement is needed following a  private or public admonishment.  The subsection should be clear that it is only applies to bans.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
The second sentence in Section 4.2 is
> Individuals whose participation
rights have been suspended from a forum may request
reinstatement.

Is this not what is asked for here?

issues.title: §1.2
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: §1.2 “whose responsibility is to further the goals of the organization” could be changed to “…goals of the IETF as an organisation” to make it clear what organisation is being discussed.

issues.author: larseggert

issues.body: I would suggest the list of changes from Section 1 and the background from Section 1.1 could be moved to an appendix, and that doing so might improve the readability of the document.

issues.title: LLC concern with Section 3
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: a concern with Section 3 Roles and Responsibilities and the specification that Moderators are responsible for "attendee lists". There are at least three of these for different sets of attendees (all, new participants, companions) and they are considered an integral part of the meeting experience and therefore currently moderated by the meetings team. Also, these lists are opt-in and anyone who chooses not to participate is not disadvantaged when it comes to the standards process, which to my mind differentiates them from plenary fora. So I would prefer that removed.

issues.title: i)
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: i) In the Introduction: "It creates a moderator team to draft procedures" —> "It creates a moderator team to define procedures" as 'draft' implies producing something for someone else to approve and "define" is used later in Section 4 where this is elaborated upon though Section 2 uses "develop".

issues.title: ii)
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: ii) In 1.2 General Philosophy "The cornerstone of our philosophy is first and foremost the individual, whose responsibility is to further the goals of the organization" —> "The cornerstone of our philosophy is that individuals are responsible for furthering the goals of the organization" because a) both "cornerstone" and "first and foremost" is excessive; and b) it’s hard to read as is.

issues.title: iii)
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: iii) Section 3 "For a Working Group, the chairs should perform moderation in a way that obviates the need for moderator team involvement." seems a bit too much to ask (is moderator action then a grounds to remove chairs?), perhaps "should aim to perform"

issues.title: Stephen Farrell Comments Part 2 (combined)
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
Two messages from Stephen.  Will subdivide issues:

Hiya,

I continued reading from section 4 on, I'll try to not
repeat any issues already raised. I do have one other
issue to raise, that I'll do in a separate email as it's
maybe more controversial and less related to the text of
draft-10.

Cheers,
S.

Non-nits:

- section 4: "Any attempt to circumvent or otherwise ignore a moderation
action is a demonstration of bad faith that may warrant further
moderation." - I think this is just wrong, one cannot know for sure
such action is a demonstration of bad faith - it could be ignorance,
or cultural. I think we want to say that decision makers can factor
what they perceive as such efforts into future/additional decisions
but we don't need to say more.

- 4.2: "Requests for reinstatement may be made only a year after the
initial decision, and then only annually afterwards" - anyone can
ask, any time, I think we want to say that decision makers can choose
to take no action for a year after a decision, rather than say that
such a request can't be made. Maybe also s/year/4 months/ as I
don't see why a year is a good choice and 3 times a year matches
the IETF cadence for various things and should be long enough for
an otherwise reasonable person to have re-discovered "comity":-)

- 5.2: The LLC frequently delete errata spam. Do we need to say
anything related to that? I think the answer is "no" but forget
if that was discussed. If we did want to say something it might
be along the lines of "the LLC may operate policies they define
for handling spam in fora related to the IETF that are subject
to injection of spam (e.g. current errata processing)" but might
be better to say nothing as hopefully errata processing will be
improved soonish.

Nits:

- section 4: "comity" - not a good word choice, as noted already:-)

- 4.1: The appeals text is written as if this document is what sets
our the moderation procedures, rather than this document tasking a
team to develop such procedures. The text is probably ok though but
maybe the editors might want to look at it another time in that light.

- 4.2: "grace": more flowery language


Also:

Hiya,

I do not think this WG or this draft is imposing a censorship
regime. However, I do think that is a risk that we ought to
address.

I suggest we add an Appendix D that says that, e.g. along the
lines of:

"
Appendix D: Risks related to better IETF community moderation

There is a risk that the evolution of well-intended procedures
established following this document gives rise to a regime
where participants are censored, or feel that they are subject
to an unreasonable censorship regime, or where participants
self-censor in fear of being considered disruptive. That is a
real risk that the moderation team, and the IESG, need to always
consider as procedures for handling disruption are developed
and as those are operated.

The goal is that participants always feel free to provide
valuable technical input, even if that is unwelcome, so long
as it is provided in a manner that respects the overall goal
of the IETF, which is to make a better Internet.
"

I don't care how that sentiment/constraint is expressed nor
where, but I do think we ought say it directly somewhere.

Cheers,
S.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: Note that the nits have been separately addressed in other issues.

issues.title: Circumvention
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
section 4: "Any attempt to circumvent or otherwise ignore a moderation
action is a demonstration of bad faith that may warrant further
moderation." - I think this is just wrong, one cannot know for sure
such action is a demonstration of bad faith - it could be ignorance,
or cultural. I think we want to say that decision makers can factor
what they perceive as such efforts into future/additional decisions
but we don't need to say more.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
> one cannot know for sure
> such action is a demonstration of bad faith - it could be ignorance,
> or cultural

I don't agree. If someone gets a note from the moderators saying "you can't post to this list for X days because Y", and then they go and make a new email address and post again, it's hard to think of how this could be ignorance or cultural.

issues.title: Reinstatement
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
From Stephen:

- 4.2: "Requests for reinstatement may be made only a year after the
initial decision, and then only annually afterwards" - anyone can
ask, any time, I think we want to say that decision makers can choose
to take no action for a year after a decision, rather than say that
such a request can't be made. Maybe also s/year/4 months/ as I
don't see why a year is a good choice and 3 times a year matches
the IETF cadence for various things and should be long enough for
an otherwise reasonable person to have re-discovered "comity":-)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Does this matter?

issues.title: more on spam
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
From Stephen:

- 5.2: The LLC frequently delete errata spam. Do we need to say
anything related to that? I think the answer is "no" but forget
if that was discussed. If we did want to say something it might
be along the lines of "the LLC may operate policies they define
for handling spam in fora related to the IETF that are subject
to injection of spam (e.g. current errata processing)" but might
be better to say nothing as hopefully errata processing will be
improved soonish.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I don't think we need to say anything about that.

issues.title: New text on addressing risk of malicious or inappropriate censorship
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
I do not think this WG or this draft is imposing a censorship
regime. However, I do think that is a risk that we ought to
address.

I suggest we add an Appendix D that says that, e.g. along the
lines of:

"
Appendix D: Risks related to better IETF community moderation

There is a risk that the evolution of well-intended procedures
established following this document gives rise to a regime
where participants are censored, or feel that they are subject
to an unreasonable censorship regime, or where participants
self-censor in fear of being considered disruptive. That is a
real risk that the moderation team, and the IESG, need to always
consider as procedures for handling disruption are developed
and as those are operated.

The goal is that participants always feel free to provide
valuable technical input, even if that is unwelcome, so long
as it is provided in a manner that respects the overall goal
of the IETF, which is to make a better Internet.
"

I don't care how that sentiment/constraint is expressed nor
where, but I do think we ought say it directly somewhere.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I fully disagree that this is a "real risk". It's at best hypothetical.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: It should go to the list. The challenge is that "censorship" must be balanced with "entitlement". So, if you're repeatedly saying something, maybe people just don't care! That's not an objection exactly, but it can be exhausting.

issues.title: Announcements
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
**Proposal**
Some lists (e.g. TLS) want to allow non-IETF announcements, if they are pre-approved

**Describe the solution you'd like**
>    *  Announcements of conferences, events, or activities that are not sponsored or endorsed by the Internet Society or IETF;
>
> Over in TLS, the chairs discussed this particular bullet a couple of months ago and while we don’t want to get spammed we don’t have a problem with announcements as long as they are pre-approved;

These bullet points are actually difficult to write. How about:

"Unauthorized announcements of conferences, events, or activities that are not sponsored or endorsed by the Internet Society or IETF;"

https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/unauthorized

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
"Unauthorized messages announcing conferences [...]"

**Additional context**
Not attached to any wording here, just kind of a crummy issue of the wording "Unauthorized announcement" being read as a property of the announcement itself (like "the conference authorized the announcement"). So maybe something else would be better.

comments.author: russhousley

reviews.body: I respectfully disagree with Russ. I don't think the policy of actively monitoring some lists and not others violates the uniformity of the criteria etc.  It simply recognizes that some lists are more general than others and therefore deserve more attention.

comments.author: russhousley

pulls.title: Bump actions/upload-artifact from 3 to 4
pulls.author: dependabot
pulls.body:
Bumps [actions/upload-artifact](https://github.com/actions/upload-artifact) from 3 to 4.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/upload-artifact's releases.

v4.0.0

What's Changed

The release of upload-artifact@v4 and download-artifact@v4 are major changes to the backend architecture of Artifacts. They have numerous performance and behavioral improvements.

ℹ️ However, this is a major update that includes breaking changes. Artifacts created with versions v3 and below are not compatible with the v4 actions. Uploads and downloads must use the same major actions versions. There are also key differences from previous versions that may require updates to your workflows.

For more information, please see:

pulls.body: Just interpret the magic words as plain English, because this is not an interoperability spec. Did not apply bold face.

Is it the IESG, or is it the IETF Chair? My original doc homed it with the Chair, since that's where the current "special-case" moderation is homed. We can change it to the IESG, but it will require other changes in the doc.
I'm good with the IETF chair.  Will change accordingly.
Not disagreeing, but maybe we need to be clear whether this is confidential, and if so whether the IETF Chair can expose it to the whole IESG.

Let's not make the chair create that, let's require the moderation team to create (and moderate, hah) that forum.

(Pet peeve of mine is the org piling more things on the IETF chair, see my chair-may-delegate draft.)
That 14-day text is much too prescriptive. Let's instead require that the moderation team must define gradual reporting of actions.

That's not appropriate in this instance.  The community is directed to that forum by this document, and only the IESG should be telling the community where to go.  I realize that this is "chair dumping" but in this case, it's a very rare event.
I disagree.  This is a matter of accountability **of** the moderator team **to** the community, and they cannot specify their own terms in that regard.

I agree with Eliot here. I think the day count is not too important. We can always try 14 days and adjust it in the inevitable update (it is difficult to imagine getting everything right the first time).

The reason my document gives the moderation team a lot of power is so that they don't have to use it most of the time.
Rather than hard-coding 14 days, we probably need $REPORTING-INTERVAL so that it can be changed without a new RFC... But I agree with Eliot about accountability.
I also agree about accountability. But I think it is enough to say that the mod team MUST adhere to reasonable and proportional reporting, rather than detailing the "how" of it.

Going to have to give you an 🙄 eyeroll emoji on this one, sorry. 14 days is a long time, and doesn't really constrain the moderator team. We do have to pick a number to set the boundary.

6 seconds? 6 minutes? 6 days? All too short.

6 weeks? That is a really long time.

Besides, the looming deadline is an excellent tool: "I'm sorry, it's out of my hands, the IETF requires a public report after 14 days". The idea is that you never get there, and so it is actually helpful to set some dumb time limit. (n.b. the moderators count the days)
My concern is the subject of a moderation action doing an appeal if it's been 15 days.
OK. Please rebase and then let's put this on the IESG, too.
OK, if everyone wants to be prescriptive, I'm in the rough.

comments.body:
If we keep this, I suggest we add
```suggestion
action to the moderator team with a few constraints.  Examples of
actions that could be taken include:

- Review and approval of submissions/messages;
```

The current moderator team (for ietf-discuss) defines its policies and processes **without** the IESG needing to approve them. Why change this? Isn't the appeals path sufficient here? Introducing the IESG into any loop causes delays, always.

reviews.author: DavidSchinazi
reviews.body: Overall I think this is a great change. Some details inline

comments.body:
I'm not 100% clear what "suspend such actions" means here. I'm assuming this means that the chairs can suspend the actions that were previously taken by the moderators? In that case, I'd suggest something like "Working group chairs MAY overrule actions from the moderators in their respective groups, if they believe..."

I would even add that if the chairs do overrule the moderators, they need to publicly explain why on the list.

Also, should we clarify the appeals chain? If a WG chair overrules a moderator, and the moderator strongly disagrees, what is the recourse?
* the moderator cannot directly appeal but a WG participant can appeal this as any regular chair decision (appeal to the responsible AD, then IESG, then IAB)
* the moderator can appeal this using the moderation appeals chain (IESG then IAB)
@DavidSchinazi I'll push another update in the next days to address the above.
@DavidSchinazi we should be careful not to stoke a debate on the working group lists.  that debate **can** happen, if necessary, but it should not be on the WG list (IMHO).

```suggestion
team diversity.  The moderation team may expand or contract
```
Because team diversity is important, so that when the team has consensus for a decision, they can be reasonably sure it's warranted. You do **not** want a team that has "no moderation ever" points of view on it, as "diverse" as that may be.

```suggestion
The moderator team will consist of no less than five
```
Because I see no point in there ever being less than five in normal operation.
Why did you move this and the following paragraph out of the "Membership" subsection? Gratuitous edits like that make it hard to spot actual changes in a PR.
Typo fixing is good, but the re-wrapping obscures actual wording changes. Please minimize.

I do **not** think chairs should be able to overrule unilaterally. *If* we end up in this situation, maybe the IESG or at least the responsible AD needs to get involved. (And yes, that means the IESG is involved, which some don't like. If we want to keep the IESG out of it, chairs need to stay out of it, since they report to the ADs.)
Hey Lars, I'm the one who wants to be prescriptive ;-). But in this case, I don't see the point in hardcoding a #.

@larseggert I added some text around this, but the point is that chairs know or should know their groups far better than moderators.  That being said, ADs need to be kept in the loop when this happens, and if it becomes a real cause for concern, the AD should change out the chair.
You had mixed composition and scope.  I am attempting to separate.  More to come on this.

The point of the moderation team is to establish an IETF-wide baseline for moderation. "The chairs know their group better" sounds to me a lot like "some groups are special", i.e., there should somehow be a higher bar for moderation of problematic behavior. I don't think we want that.

Can you give an example of a case where chair discretion should trump a moderator team decision?
yes but please permit me to do so out of band, since it names names.
An insignificant nit, but I think that we should avoid RFC 2119 language since this isn't a protocol, and hence use the same words in lowercase.
MUST NOT => cannot

I'm not sure about excluding the LLC staff/contractors.  Having some folks on their who part of their job role is to help with the moderation may be beneficial, although I can understand why you want to try and keep them separate.
SHALL => may

I don't think that a WG chair should be able to override an IETF wide moderation decision.  E.g., if the moderation teams decides to ban someone from posting to any IETF list for 5 days, then I don't think that a WG chair should be able to say "except they can post to mine".  However, I also think that this is likely to be a non-issue as in, I doubt that a WG chair would choose to do this anyway.  But stating the ultimate authority is probably still useful.
Not sure on this.  I think that anyone should be able to appeal any decision and it should just take the normal escalation path.

Ted Lemon and I also got into this issue on the list. This is brief:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/mod-discuss/KCGz70SboXFXo3xc55E4QD2vbRE/

I think it's correct to exclude staff, because some (many?) moderation decisions may directly impact the standards process, and that is a strict NO for staff. However, as I've said before and will say again if necessary, staff must be able to perform emergency moderation when a posting is manifestly obscene, illegal or part of a detected DOS attack.

To clarify my position: I was mainly pointing out that the text as written was slightly unclear. At this point in time, I don't yet have a fully formed opinion on whether chairs should be able to overrule moderators or not. But we'll definitely need to pick an answer to that binary question before we publish this. Would love to hear the example out of band too if you think that's appropriate.
I'd say _soft_code a number, by qualifying it with 'normally'. Otherwise, if we hard code a minimum, and one resigns, we're in trouble.
Let's be clear: there will be normative procedural statements here.
We will take this up in another PR
Not in this PR
I take your point.
I've now moved diversity into the team composition section
Text removed
@rgwilton as you know I initially thought Jay should do this job, but it's now raising some legal concerns if we break down the barrier.
I will revert this change and open a separate issue, so that it can be discussed on the list.
Resolved by 595112b.
This needs more commentary on list.
See last commit to address mailing list discussion.  @larseggert I may have biffed the rebase; could you eye it over?
nevermind.  Working on it.
Ok, please review.
@DavidSchinazi please have another look, if you have time.
@rgwilton I'd like not to try to solve this in this PR.  If you feel strongly, could you open an issue?

Overall I agree with the general mindset and decision-making here. However, when it gets down to implementation, I think the details leave an unspecified window that is open to interpretation.

Let's take a hypothetical scenario:
* Alice is a long-time contributor of the FOO WG
* Alice sends an email to the FOO WG mailing list that the moderators find to be inappropriate
* A moderator replies that this was inappropriate and asks Alice to do better
* Alice digs their heels in, and repeats the offensive behavior
* [time T0] The moderator reaches out privately to the chairs saying that they want to block Alice's email to the FOO WG list for 2 weeks
* The FOO WG chair says that the moderator is overreacting and shouldn't take such a drastic measure because Alice is an important contributor and the topic at hand is a WGLC that will expire before those 2 weeks
* The moderator and FOO WG chair talk but are unable to come to agreement
* This gets escalated to the responsible AD for FOO, who decides to side with the moderator
* [time T1] the moderator goes into the admin interface and puts Alice in moderation

In this example, the time delay between T0 and T1 could be multiple days. That's too much time as it could allow the list discussion to spiral out of control. So "something" needs to happen between T0 and T1, even if "something" is "let Alice keep posting" - in this context, inaction is still an action. So my question is: can we clarify what happens between T0 and T1 in this scenario? Options include:
* Alice's posting rights are maintained
* Alice's emails are moderated by the moderator
* Alice's emails are moderated by the WG chair
* Alice's emails are blocked
* Both the moderator and chair have access to the admin interface so they play admin tennis constantly undoing the other's action to get the list in the state they want it to be in
* We take the entire Internet offline and all go touch grass

Another way to phrase this whole thing could be to say that the moderator is allowed to put the block in place, but must immediately notify the chairs. If the chairs disagree, they can follow the usual appeals process, but aren't allowed to undo the moderator's action themselves until either they come to an agreement with the moderator, or the appeal is adjudicated.
@larseggert the only thing that seems to have been blown is ietf chair to iesg.  do you see others?
@DavidSchinazi Ok, I think I've closed that loophole with the latest commit.  Let me know if you think I'm wrong.
And @DavidSchinazi, if I'm still missing, we can reword along you're lines.
This latest text works for me, thanks

Not going to argue about the placement, but I think that is a pretty strong abstract. You don't need context there. :)

I always try to suggest text, since one thing people often say is "why not open a PR?" when someone is just arguing. But that doesn't mean I am being insistent.

Edit: I might also add that the README says "Contributions can be made by creating pull requests." (subject to the usual Note Well material). Here, you have a well-written opener. I think anyone would perk up at that opening sentence vs "This document describes the creation of a moderation team...". I think you are missing that the first task is to get people to read the document in the first place.  Now, do you want to let Rob write that? The trick here is this: you write one sentence about good things like empathy, honesty, and kindness. Then you flip to the "This document describes..." stuff with no verbal transition. It makes the procedural text much more powerful. If you look at my PR here, just imagine a "👀" in the break after the first sentence. I don't care if you use my exact words.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
I got to this version, but only to back up my comments (take it or leave it).

"The cornerstone of our philosophy is first and foremost the individual, whose responsibility is to further the goals of the organization {{!RFC3935}} in a manner consistent with the policy laid out in {{!RFC7154}}.

The IETF is an open standards organization. Engaged, respectful discussion within the scope of a forum is not considered abuse, nor should someone be considered abusive solely because they are outside the rough consensus. Disagreement and diverse points of view within any standards organization are to be expected and are even healthy.  With that in mind, moderators are expected to identify when someone has crossed a line, and what action is appropriate. When someone crosses the line into disruptive behavior, some action must be taken to maintain the decorum of the community.

Moderation will be consistent and fair to encourage participation. Disagreements may be appealed, and decisions can be
reconsidered over time.

The goal is explicitly **not** punishment, but maintaining an open, welcoming, non-hostile environment where all may participate on equal footing, regardless of their position or their past contributions."

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Maybe another case of "say less".

Here, we can take out the theorizing:

-- Since a request to be reinstated is in effect an appeal process, decisions to not reinstate someone may not be appealed again.

Then,

++ There is no requirement to continually evaluate these decisions. It is reasonable to revisit these decisions after a year.

That should cover litigious weirdos and DoS attacks on appeals, but also give the moderators/chairs a guideline.

comments.author: becarpenter

comments.author: sayrer

Well, I was going for "you can appeal anything, but not every week for a year". I think it's better to state it this way, so it's clear you are wasting your time. If someone said something crappy a few years ago, that's not grounds for a lifetime ban, but it is also not cool to hear from them every week hammering on the same issue. That is abuse.

comments.author: elear

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: @elear, I think you need to touch section 2.5 "Appeals" as well, since it says "_any_ moderation decision can be appealed to the IESG". We can't just cancel that in the very next paragraph. Perhaps we need to narrow the grounds of appeal somehow? We obviously want to prevent vexatious and repetitious appeals, but we need to allow appeals on the grounds of unfairness. This is very tricky to get right.

pulls.title: Circumvention demonstrates bad faith
pulls.author: larseggert
pulls.body: Suggestion from an IETF participant at 112.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Hmm, I think it crosses over with #77.

You totally can circumvent IETF moderation, and even CC the IETF while doing it. That does not (necessarily) seem like bad faith to me, but a disagreement. That is why I opened #77. It might be that your opinions are not too interesting.

That is different from creating a new email account and abusing the IETF's infrastructure with your new account that no one reads other than on IETF lists.

So, is it the sort of "free speech" which will drive people away? Is it an "unpopular opinion", maybe only stated once? Pretty much the point of my input: the IETF can say "cool it" for a short period of time with no public record. Everyone has gotten worked up in an argument a few times. My draft is way better at describing this part, tbh, but "circumvention" is too vague in this diff.

But in the interest of "rough consensus," it is fine. It will come up again, though.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I think the text I proposed is unclear. The issue that was describes to me is if someone under moderation circumvents that _and continues posting in the forum they were blocked from_.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
It's almost right. I think you mean that they take actions such that IETF mailing list (or equivalent) users still receive their messages. Maybe something like "continues to take advantage of distribution from IETF infrastructure".

Actions that intend to avoid a ban on distribution. If banned, I can email some pastebin thing and CC an IETF list. No big deal. The pastebin readers might notice that I CCed an IETF list, but it didn't show up in the IETF archive.

I think we have to accept this exposure of moderation actions since the IETF designed this system.

- More than one and you must separate with commas.  Example: On a dark night, in a cold house, David lit a fire.
- A single but long phrase.  In the middle of a war in the Pacific, Harry and Ito got drunk on a bottle of saki.

We should not assume that because we all know the appendix is non-normative, that someone who gets moderated will accept that as an explanation for why their lawyering doesn't work.

> An easier approach would be to drop the word. Also, keep in mind that we are in a non-normative appendix.

Yep, my proposal is purposely not as concise as it could be. But certainly it's editorial. Up to you.

Instead of aiming for just the right level of condescension, another option is to leave out the condescension and use a few extra words, as in, "These are examples. They are not intended to be limiting."

But I agree that the editors should use their editorial discretion and that this shed will hold the necessary bikes no matter what color we paint it.

```suggestion
These items are examples. If a particular example of moderation cannot
```
@elear like this?

```suggestion
These items are examples. Whether a particular instance where moderation occurred
matches an example in this list has no bearing
on whether the moderation action was warranted. Lack of such a match
therefore cannot serve as a basis for an appeal.
```

Ooh, I don't know. Since I didn't like using "whether" twice, here is a short one. Feel free to mix and match:

"These items are examples. Other moderation actions can be warranted. An absence from this list therefore cannot serve as the basis for an appeal."

Something like this phrasing serves the same purpose as "merely". It's clear that the document is using a sharp knife.
Actually, I would prefer that we remove all text "These items are examples."  That statement makes clear that other possibilities exist.

Well, the aim around this text is to address the concern Lars raises here:

https://youtu.be/kqnCi-BErs0?si=d4ZO6OFKTupm93cQ&t=466

So, being very concise might give rise to people getting confused about that list. People who run into this appendix are probably not thinking very calmly. But if Lars is ok with being very brief, it's fine with me. He would know more about the value of pre-empting appeals.
Nothing we say here will stop an appeal. It might at best stop some confused emails.

The point isn't to stop an appeal. It's to quickly eliminate the early exchanges in the appeal. The point is that if it's said explicitly that this isn't an exhaustive list and that not being on this list isn't grounds for an appeal, that's one quick exchange either eliminated or streamlined. It's not that someone with a bee in their bonnet isn't going to come up with something else.

Along the lines of what @sayrer suggested:
```suggestion
These items are examples. Moderators and administrators may take moderation actions for many other cases. 
```
It's excessive.  The title of the section is "Non-normative Examples of Disruptive Behavior".    The key term is **non-normative**.
I think this is addressed in the other thread.  @Abhayakara @sayrer please review the committed changes.

pulls.title: Proposal for notification requirements
pulls.author: chris-box
pulls.body:
Following the brief discussion in the WG meeting, I offered to propose new wording. While considering what to write here, I realised that it would be good to give moderators discretion to take a light-touch approach in borderline cases. For example if a particular post is in the grey area between civil and uncivil, it may be useful to place the sender in hold for moderation for a few days so that if a subsequent message crosses the line, it can be prevented from reaching the list.

The alternative is that we require moderators to always notify the affected person about holds. If we take this route, moderators are likely to refrain from taking action in borderline cases, and wait until the line has been crossed. In this scenario some damage (e.g. to newcomer participation) is incurred.

I would appreciate WG thoughts on this wording.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
How about an editorial change along these lines:
>Individuals whose participation
rights have been suspended **indefinitely** from a forum may request
reinstatement.

I think we need to think about this a bit more.

If someone's posting rights have been suspended for some period, there is no need for letting them ask for reinstatement before that period is over. (We could even say they get automatically restored, but that is maybe a detail best left to the mod team.)

If someone's posting rights have been suspended _indefinitely_, then I think we should say after what time they can ask for reinstatement. (I personally think a year is fine.)
isn't this the point of a reinstatement request though, i.e. to request before the waiting period is over?
I hope not? If someone has lost their posting rights for a period, under what conditions would they be reinstated early?

e.g. if they acknowledged the behaviour that led to the moderation action + committed to keep the peace.  Clemency is widely understood as being a reasonable thing across many cultures. Sometimes people have a bad day, or a bad week, but later climb down off their perch.

Secondly, if the policy allows indefinite suspension but with the possibility of reinstatement, what does that mean? Is someone reinstated by default after a specific period of time if they ask, no strings attached?  In which case it's not clear what the practical difference is between a fixed suspension term, and indefinite suspension with automatic reinstatement.

I.e. what's the strategy here? Should it be rules-based (i.e. hardline) or discretion-based (i.e. clemency)?

> e.g. if they acknowledged the behaviour that led to the moderation action + committed to keep the peace. 

Past experience is that participants who are able to self-regulate in this way never make it to the stage where their posting rights are suspended, i.e., whomever this applies to have been given chances like that and failed to take them.

> Secondly, if the policy allows indefinite suspension but with the possibility of reinstatement, what does that mean?

I don't think we want to allow this. That is what the original "one year" text was supposed to address.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This memo makes the following changes:
```

```suggestion
For a working group, chairs are assumed to be administrators.  While they may
devolve this responsibility, they must always make clear to complainants and
moderators  who is responsible for resolving a complaint in a timely fashion.
Forum administrators should perform moderation in a way that
```

Lint

```suggestion
(such as reviewing messages prior to delivery to a mailing list), and
*reactive* moderation,
```

Can we find a simpler word than `devolve`?

Maybe
```
For a working group, chairs are by default the administrators.  They may
delegate this responsibility, but it must always transparently communicated
who holds this role and is hence taking moderation actions on behalf of the chairs.
Forum administrators should perform moderation in a way that
```
I think "delegate" is what's typically used here, at least in American English. This is a good explanation: https://hinative.com/questions/23265760

```suggestion
For a working group, chairs are by default the administrators.  They may
delegate this responsibility, but it must always transparently communicated
who holds this role and is hence taking moderation actions on behalf of the chairs.
Forum administrators should perform moderation in a way that
```
That's not sufficient.  Chairs must take responsibility for receiving complaints.  That cannot be delegated.  How they are processed can be.
Does what I wrote imply that is not so? (I don't see it.)

If it is implied it is oblique at best.  Let's be unambiguous.  How about:
```suggestion
For a working group, chairs are by default the administrators.  They may
delegate this responsibility, but they must always accept, acknowledge,
and keep track of complaints of disruptive behavior.
Forum administrators should perform moderation in a way that
```

```suggestion
Further appeals may be made to the IESG per {{Section 6.5.2 of !RFC2026}}.
```

As you know, the appeal to the IAB is not an option, it's an escalation. I'd actually prefer to not even mention that, since the pointer to 2026 should be sufficient.
I think this could be fixed with the term 'further appeal'...

pulls.title: Clarify relationship to IRTF
pulls.author: DavidSchinazi
pulls.body: Based on [the list dicussion](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/mod-discuss/DwGwGt0W-2FZ7pKX-WIKBjm42wY/), it sounds like the goal is for these policies to not apply to the IRTF. Let's make that crystal clear then.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @csperkins ?

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: I accepted Lars's suggestion from Colin. That removes the ambiguity for me, so I'm happy with this
I would leave the IRSG the option to apply these rules, should they choose to do so.

Yeah, it seems a bit redundant. This part is already in there: "a peer organization separate from the IETF that is governed by its own set or rules and processes."

But there is a typo! Should be "its own set *of* rules and processes." Maybe it will read a bit easier with that fixed.
Thanks. I've fixed the typo and mentioned that this is true at the time of publication but could change in the future

OK, if you really feel strongly about this one, how about:

"The policies described here do not apply to IRTF fora such as research group mailing lists.  The
IRSG may choose to change that in the future."

So, no "at the time" stuff. I would not add this text, but I do not feel strongly.
I'm ambivalent about this. I think "the IRTF is governed by its own rules" already makes it clear enough this doc doesn't apply.

This can also be read as implying that the IRSG should choose to do so, which is debatable. If the existing text is unclear, I'd prefer to add "The policies described in this memo do not apply to the IRTF." and nothing more.
(Aside: did my WGLC comment about whether this applies to IAB-, RSWG-, and Independent Stream-managed forums get captured somewhere?)
It did now :-) #227 Sorry for missing it.
No worries

```suggestion
in the IRTF and moderation of IRTF participation fora.
The policies described in this memo do not apply to the IRTF.
```
I think this is the change @csperkins suggested.
I still think this is redundant, but it's not something to argue about, as long as @DavidSchinazi also thinks it is ok.

pulls.title: Add communication from ombudsteam
pulls.author: DavidSchinazi
pulls.body:
The draft does a good job of covering communications from the administrators to the ombudsteam, but I would suggest adding text about the inverse direction.

_(David, writing as an individual)_

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @peteresnick? (I assume this is the right GitHub ID, apologies if it is not.)
I'm not sure this is possible, given the "cone of silence" around the Ombudsteam.

Yes, I think this would be a problem. If the ombudsteam is *confidentially* notified about some behavior that doesn't rise to the level of harassment, the ombudsteam can encourage the reporter to notify the chair/administrator, or the mod team in the alternative. If the reporter asks an ombudsperson to help out (maybe the reporter feels uncomfortable making the report), and the ombudsperson also believes that the behavior is disruptive, the ombudsperson can make a report to the chair/administrator/mod-team, but that's as an individual. The ombudsteam should not get into the business of being a conduit for reports that should have gone to the chair/administrator/mod-team in the first place, both because it will sound like it's coming from some level of authority (which the PR text seems to imply) and because it will end up with far too many reports to the ombudsteam.

Aside from that, the charter is quite clear: "The revising or redefining of related Ombudsteam policies or practices such as [RFC7776](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7776/) [...] is out of scope." And the document even says quite clearly: "Dealing with _disruptive_ behavior, however, is not part of the role of the ombudsteam."

Let's not do this.
After thinking about this some more - and a very helpful offline conversation with Pete - I agree that this change isn't right. I'll close this PR.

pulls.title: Reword composition text
pulls.author: DavidSchinazi
pulls.body:
The composition text was somewhat unclear to me, and did not handle cases of resignations from the moderator team. The proposed new text attempts to resolve these issues while still providing the IESG with the flexibility to recall a moderator if needed.

This text was inspired by Section 3.1 of RFC 7776.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @elear and I wordsmithed this in #224.
Would you mind restoring the original line breaks (as far as possible), so that the diff highlights actual changes?

We can't quite predict the future yet, regardless of what several RFCs might say.
```suggestion
membership, but the IESG should endeavor to rapidly appoint
new moderators to
```

Also, this makes a pretty significant change, in that it requires a floor of five, whereas the current text is about an initial size that might well drop below five if the IESG finds that useful. Because the current text talks about an initial size, it also does not talk about rapidly needing to find more people. I think that is a feature.

@DavidSchinazi is reacting (correctly, I think) to Chris Box's point that there needs to be a minimum of five moderators for the moderators' own sanity/avoidance of burnout.  I was concerned that we wouldn't get even five (it's probably not going to be a fun job- oh the glory!).  But Chris certainly won me over with his argument that we do at least need to start with five.
Done

If we just require an initial number of five, then the number could drop to three, and that could lead to burnout for a couple more, and all of a sudden we end up with one or zero moderators. I think we should strive to stay above five, to avoid burnout. The text is specifically worded to not be a hard floor, just a strong suggestion to the IESG
I think what we said at some point also was to let this number float based on operational experience.

For the ombudsteam, the RFC floor was 3 but in practice we generally have 5 people these days. We could do the same here. But I do think having a floor is helpful. As someone who would consider putting my name in as a potential moderator - knowing that there's a sizable team to work with is quite important so I know I'm not signing up for an unbounded amount of work. I think a floor of 5 is reasonable personally

I'm fine with starting at five. But I was going to simply leave it to the mod team and the IESG to discuss how many are appropriate afterwards. If the mod team feels like the load is to high, surely they can tell the IESG "find us more"?

I think there is a distinction is between intentional mod team size changes and unintentional ones. If the IESG deems that [three is the right number](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xOrgLj9lOwk), then that's OK. But if we al think that five is the right number, but two moderators resign and the IESG is too busy to find two new people to appoint, then we have an understaffed team. A potential solution to this is to add something like "`The IESG is allowed to change the size of the moderator team by issuing an IESG statement.`" but at that point it might be process overkill. We could also just remove any discussion of a specific number and just say something like "`If there are too many resignations from the moderator team to the point that it no longer operates well, the IESG will rapidly appoint new moderators to
bring the size back up.`"
Nothing we put in this document will prevent an IESG from mismanaging this team in a million ways. We just have to trust that they know what they are doing, i.e., trust NomCom.

That's absolutely true, but I don't think the current text in this section does a great job then. As an example, it doesn't allow the IESG to recall a moderator - which is something I think the IESG should be able to do.

Hmm, it's there though.

https://larseggert.github.io/draft-ietf-modpod-group-processes/draft-ietf-modpod-group-processes.html#section-2.1

"The IESG appoints and replaces moderators."

So, does @DavidSchinazi think that does not include recall?

This is a very picky document, so I could understand if he doesn't. It's enough for me, though.
I think a narrow reading of "replaces" is that they couldn't just remove someone without naming someone else. The "recalls" in @DavidSchinazi's proposed changes is a better term.

```suggestion
The moderator team initially consists of no less than five
individuals. The moderator team may expand or contract
based on operational experience.
The IESG appoints and recalls moderators.
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
Apart from appointing and recalling
```

```suggestion

In selecting members, the IESG will take into
```

```suggestion

The IESG appoints and recalls moderators.
```

pulls.title: Attempt to address spt's comment on Announcements.
pulls.author: sayrer
pulls.body:
The TLS WG likes to allow pre-approved announcements. I'm sure there are other groups that do as well (DNS OARC, things like that).

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/mod-discuss/lDBRz4iWw077lYYNCgZjClY6OXY/

This is my attempt, feel free to change the wording. Should close #221.

comments.body:
"Unauthorized" here raises the question "who can authorize", so maybe

```suggestion
- Messages announcing conferences, events, or activities
  that are not sponsored or endorsed by the Internet Society or IETF,
  unless posted with prior approval of list administrators;
```

pulls.title: Address comments from Chris Box and Brian Carpenter regarding the first point in Appendix C
pulls.author: sayrer
pulls.body:
See the discussion here:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/mod-discuss/t_lO3RgjlkeRztMb4NDh-kCzVRo/

This one is my fault, as I did indeed just copy/paste the old version from the IETF list policies.

Stephen Farrell raised the point that sometimes a group is chartered to define a charter, but I think we're still covered on that one, especially given the text on approved charters below.

comments.body:
This is not only for (working) groups, so we need to be a bit more general; maybe

```suggestion
- Discussion of subjects unrelated to a forum's charter or scope;
```

pulls.title: Trim and add 7282 reference
pulls.author: elear
pulls.body: This change consolidates some text, and adds a reference to RFC 7282.

comments.author: Abhayakara
comments.body: WFM

Alternative sugestion.
```
The IETF is an open standards organization with a discussion-based rough
consensus process, non-normatively described in {{?RFC7282}}.
Engaged, respectful
discussion that is within the scope of an IETF forum should therefore not be considered disruptive,
nor should someone be considered disruptive solely because they are outside the rough
consensus.disruptive.  
```
This sentence about RFC7282 reads like a non-sequitur to me.
How about "...process. RFC7282 provides a non-normative description of the consensus process."
(I really don't like "non-normatively". :)

pulls.title: add moderators into the disposition cycle
pulls.author: elear
pulls.body: Arguably they were already there, but this makes it clear that they review actions taken by administrators.

comments.body:
```suggestion
A group taking a moderation actions that restrict participation privileges,
i.e., either administrators or moderators, shall periodically report them to the IESG,
as well as immediately to the respective other group for their information, and to
those against whom those actions take effect.
```
Since there are two groups that can take such actions. I'm not in love with my rewording, since it's complicated...
Nah- I think it's sufficiently understood without the change.

What does "periodically" mean here?  Would it be consistent with the document if an anonymous member of the moderator's team ban someone, and have a personal policy of reporting that to the banned person once every other month?  I think that would be unfortunate, but it seems within reason given current wordings.
"Periodically" only applies to reporting to the IESG. It's "immediately" for the other group and the affected.

> "Periodically" only applies to reporting to the IESG. It's "immediately" for the other group and the affected.

I don't think "immediately" in that sentence apply to the person whom the action applies to.  "immediately" is only used for "to the respective other group for their information".
Note the "and to those against whom those actions take effect"? It applies there as well.

```suggestion
as well as immediately to the moderator team for their review, and
immediately to those against whom those actions take effect.
```

pulls.title: go back to 6.5.1 but require transparency
pulls.author: elear

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @peteresnick, @elear and me discussed this just now, and we think that Section 6.5.2 of RFC2026 **does** apply here, since paragraph 4 of 6.5.2 which raised with Eliot (`If circumstances warrant`) cannot apply, because circumstances described here won't ever warrant.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: @larseggert please review.
Isn't appeals transparency already handled by existing processes?
Section 6.5.1 of 2026 does not make that clear, and I would not want to introduce any ambiguities.
I'm with you, but I don't think this is the document to revamp the appeals process, or even part of it.
Unless you really want to open the `Updates: 2026` can of worms :-)
I don't think we're doing that.  We're just saying how that section of 2026 applies here.

A suggestion, just to keep it parallel to 2026: "If the disagreement cannot be resolved by the Area Director, that person may then appeal to the IESG, and subsequently to the IAB, using the process stated in
{{Section 6.5.1 of !RFC2026}} and following the procedure of {{Section 6.5.4 of !RFC2026}}." 6.5.4 requires communication.
Except I think we now mean 6.5.2, no?
No, 6.5.2 is still absolutely not what we want, for all of the reasons I mentioned in email.
Ok, have a look at the current proposed text.

It's OK. I like my wording better because it then parallels 2026 better, but I don't think the current text will cause active harm (unless someone decides that there is some significant difference between "discussing a disagreement" and "raising an appeal").
Ok, take another look.
Peachy.
